questions.text: In which country would you find Casablanca?
In which part of the world would you find a duck-billed platypus?
Name the biggest city in Australia.
Name the fast-growing grass that soon looks like a tall tree.
questions.explanation:
Bamboo.

	Bamboo can reach heights of 130 feet in the largest species.

questions.text: What is the national sport in Brazil?
questions.explanation:
Football.

	Called 'futebol' in Brazil (and 'futbol' other Latin countries), the sport is known as soccer in the USA.

questions.text: Name the world's longest mountain range.
questions.explanation:
Andes.

	The world's longest mountain range stretches for 7,200 km in South America.

questions.text: Name Africa's largest country.
questions.explanation:
Algeria.

	Sudan was the biggest, until South Sudan voted in January 2011 to become a separate country. It became a sovereign nation later that year and joined the United Nations in 14th July 2011.

questions.text: Baggataway was a ball game played by Canadian Indians which developed into the modern game of ....?
The Palio, a famous horse-race, is run in the main square of which Italian city?
Which country's blue and white flag represents the country's lakes and snowfields?
At which art gallery would you see Leonardo da Vinci's 'Mona Lisa'?
The 'Skeleton Coast' is part of the Namib Desert which acquired its name from ....?
By 1914 the whole of Africa had either been colonized or supervised by a European power except which two countries?
The Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, California was the world's longest suspension bridge when it opened in what year?
What were the first names of the English painter L.S. Lowry?
Alfred Mosher Butts invented the word game Scrabble. He estimated the values of the letters by their occurrence on a single front page of which paper?
questions.explanation:
The New York Times.

	It was first sold as 'Lexico' in 1946.

questions.text: The only country in South Asia never to be colonized by any European power was ______?
questions.explanation:
Siam (Thailand).

	France colonized Vietnam and Germany colonized part of Northern New Guinea. Both Spain then America colonized the Philippines. Britain ruled India, Burma, Malaya, Northern Borneo, Sarawak and Brunei.

questions.text: What was the first name of the French sculptor Rodin?
What was the name of the rocket aircraft which Charles 'Chuck' Yeager had his first supersonic flight over the Mojave desert in California on 14th October 1947?
questions.explanation:
Glamorous Glennis.

	It was named after his wife Glennis.

questions.text: Which of the following elements are actually named for the following countries: Polonium (Poland), Francium (France), Americium (America) and Germanium (Germany)?
How long did it take the pilgrims to sail to North America aboard the Mayflower in 1620?
In 1896 the English carpenter Brian Gamlin of Bury, Lancashire is credited to the present numbering system of which game?
questions.explanation:
Darts.

	The position of the numbers on a dart board.

questions.text: Which element's name was developed from the Greek word for 'Stench'?
questions.explanation:
Bromine.

	Bromine from the Greek word 'bromos'. Chlorine comes from the Greek word 'chloros' meaning green and iodine from 'iodes' meaning violet.

questions.text: Which is the only flag of the world to have a different design on the front and the back?
questions.explanation:
Paraguay.

	The front shows the country's national seal and the back shows the design of the seal of the paraguayan treasury.

questions.text: At what approximate temperature (degrees celsius) does gold melt?
questions.explanation:
1065.

	Tin melts at 232 degrees, zinc at 419 degrees, iron and steel around 1400-1500 degrees. Hope you enjoyed the challenge.
